Award.AwardTitle: The Impact of Fire on Entrainment and Precipitation Efficiency Derived from Isotope Ratios
Award.AbstractNarration:
Biomass burning in central and southern Africa produces some of the world's most dense layers of smoke. The smoke plumes and transported over the southern Atlantic Ocean where they merge with wide areas of low altitude stratocumulus clouds. The details of how smoke aerosol particles and stratocumulus clouds interact is inadequately understood, despite the disproportionally large role those types of clouds play in local and global climate. This project seeks to improve understanding of how smoke changes the way air circulates near clouds, how cloud droplets in polluted clouds evaporate at different rates from those in pristine clouds, and how drizzle is modified when smoke is present. Stable isotope ratios of oxygen and hydrogen in water vapor and cloud liquid will be measured from aircraft flights though smoke and cloud layers near Namibia to evaluate characteristics of atmospheric mixing, cloud evaporation and the fraction of clouds droplets which grow to produce rain. These characteristics are difficult to quantify from more traditional methods. Isotopic data will be used to evaluate entrainment and evaporation simulated by the NCAR Community Earth System Model to evaluate where new understanding from the experiment can improve model simulations.

Lack of knowledge about cloud-smoke interactions leads to crude treatment of processes in climate models, which consequently leads important unresolved uncertainties in climate model simulations. The isotopic study provides a sorely needed critical check on how clouds are depicted in models and gives specific guidance as to which mechanisms are incorrectly represented. The datasets collected enable several research groups to test and compare their models using isotopic constraints which will serve as a valuable legacy of the experiment. The data-model synthesis fosters collaboration that bridges between observation and modeling specialists and enables students training in combining expertise in modeling and data methods to achieve enhanced knowledge though synthesis. The project provides opportunities to engage learning at many levels though incorporation of research experiences in class room teaching at Oregon State University and in public outreach forums.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The combination of observations and process modeling of stable isotope ratios in the region of biomass burning and clouds has clarified previously poorly understood relationships between aging of smoke, dilution of aerosols by atmospheric mixing and changes to the cloud microphysical properties when clouds are exposed to high aerosol concentrations. A large dataset of water vapor isotope profiles was collected over the Southeast Atlantic Ocean, and have provided a landmark climatological perspective on the vertical structure of isotope ratios in the atmosphere over the vertical span from the surface to the upper troposphere. The results highlight the dynamic relationship between the boundary layer and stratocumulus clouds and the horizontal transport of moisture above. The project developed a new approach to make direct measurements of cloud water isotope ratios, which capture the vertical profile of isotope ratios within clouds at spatial scales of 10s of meters that are comparable to the sensitivity of optical cloud probes. These reveal for the first time that clouds are sustained out of isotopic equilibrium due to evaporation at cloud top.

Observations have shown characteristic differences in black carbon content as a function of the isotopic ratios that implicate scavenging during precipitation formation. Precipitation upstream, over continental Africa, remove aerosols while fractionation processes deplete the remaining vapor of heavy isotopologues which is the basis of the signature of wet deposition. This feature is combined with a conserved tracer approach to fully leverage the isotopic information to constrain transport processes in the region of the biomass burning plume and near the marine trade cumulus clouds. It is found that the NCAR Community Earth System model does not depict the dilution of aerosols at cloud top and concomitant drying of the cloud layer with particularly high fidelity, likely caused in part to the scale mismatch between the model vertical resolution and the 10s-of-metres scale of the underlying mixing and entrainment processes.

Results were shared with the scientific community, school children and community members through conferences, public lectures and outreach events. The new in situ cloud droplet isotopic measurement approach is based on a dual inlet system which samples both total water and cloud condensate using a counterflow-virtual impactor. The careful control of temperature and pressure within the inlet system allows cloud droplets to be aerodynamically separated from ambient vapor without significant fractionation influences. The measurement approach has been replicated and has become available to all members of the scientific community through the NCAR aviation facility.
